And so Remnant: From The Ashes begets Remnant: 
Turns Out There Was Still A Lot Of Ashes Left,

Here&#39;s another bucket load, why
don&#39;t you have a big sift through them?
Ooh, I think that&#39;s a piece of jawbone.
Two.

We returned not quite as post-apocalyptic
as it was the last time, Earth, after the events

of Remnant 1, only this time instead of
playing as &quot;The Wanderer&quot; we play as &quot;The Traveller&quot;.

A small but significant
difference, I&#39;m sure you&#39;ll agree.

You wouldn&#39;t get far trying to paper
things on holiday with Wanderer&#39;s checks, but on

the other hand if Wordsworth had written
&quot;I travelled lonely as a cloud&quot; everyone might

have thought he was
talking about basketball fouls.

You may remember Remnant 1 as the third
person shoot his answer to soulslikes that started
out as a rather dowdy grey-brown standard

post-apocalyptic shooter
affair before suddenly turning into

a magical multi-dimensional mystery tour
that I had a surprisingly unshitty time with, and

which I probably wouldn&#39;t have
discovered if I hadn&#39;t been obliged to keep playing by

an employment contract and a
dog who&#39;s accustomed to the good stuff.

Well Remnant 2 takes the right lesson
from that by wasting as little time as possible
with the post-apocalyptic Earth poncery.

The Traveller travels, as is his wand,
to a survivor community in one of Earth&#39;s ruined
cities and gets the quick induction tour.

Hi, welcome, here&#39;s the ammo vendor,
here&#39;s where we hang the tea towels, and here&#39;s the

interdimensional portal
we keep around for some reason.

Oh you think that&#39;s
impressive, well hold my beer.

Then two of the shelter&#39;s residents
disappear into the multiverse and since the Traveller

has developed a real rapport with the
dozy gits in the 20 minutes they&#39;ve gotten to

know them they immediately travel after
them to rescue them from whatever reject sliders
episode they&#39;re currently trapped in.

Slow down, Yahtz, you need
to pick a character class first.
Do you want to be a gunslinger?
Yes.
There&#39;s actually some other classes as well.

I&#39;d assume it&#39;s much Remnant 2 but you
said something about letting me be a badass dimension

hopping cowboy like the protagonist of a
Stephen King pet project and frankly I&#39;m a little
confused as to why you feel the need to continue.
One of them has a dog.

There&#39;s such a thing as
talking past the sale, you know.

So anyway, my badass dimension
hopping cowboy starts hopping dimensions.

I loved this whole concept
in Remnant 1 and I love it now.

You take the Dark Souls formula of being in
a dying fantasy world without a bumhole stabbing

clue what&#39;s going on and extend it
across multiple dying fantasy worlds all dying for

different interesting bespoke reasons
that we have even less anal distending clues about
and it basically multiplies the effect.

And our dude being an ordinary clueless
homeboy with a base on normal if slightly banged up

earth full of NPCs going &quot;Back from
slaying nightmares from beyond the veil of time and

space I have some beans on toast and
tell us all about it&quot; gives a wonderful grounding
and juxtaposition that keeps it relatable.
I love how lacking in ceremony it all is.

Compare this experience to something like
Bayonetta where every enemy has to be introduced

with a special cinematic so it can wiggle
its bum at the camera in time with the surging
music.
Not here.

Here you&#39;re just dumped
in the Bloodborne dimension.

A bunch of screaming cockneys are trying
to chainsaw your face off, there&#39;s giant mutant

rats and angels and a ghost and all you
know is that you can&#39;t find your friends, you&#39;re

due for some target practice and you&#39;d
really rather not have your face chainsawed off.

The truly interesting can speak
for itself without needing a hype man.

Also, Remnant 2&#39;s boss
fights rarely miss the mark.

You couldn&#39;t pull a Dark Souls 2 and
load the game up with 900 copout armoured dude
with a sword fights.
It&#39;s a shooter.

we&#39;d have perforated them into cheese graters 
before they could yell &quot;charge.&quot;

So it&#39;s more often than not interesting giant
monsters with big juicy suitable weak spots.

Frequently doing interesting things with
the environment beyond big circular room and sad
music.

One highlight for me was fighting a
bunch of rotating cubes in a giant maze puzzle that

was like having to outwit
an executive toy from the inside.

However, with my ongoing struggle with
souls-like fatigue I have less and less patience for

what we academically call &quot;bullshit
attacks&quot; and sometimes it feels like edging ever closer

to bullshit city limits is the
only way new souls-likes try to innovate.

There&#39;s this one boss fight against a
ghost lady I was stuck on for a while because of

this one grab attack that you basically
have to be at full health to survive, which he

only pulls out in like the last quarter
of the fight so it took many failed attempts

to finally trial and error my way to
figuring out the specific direction I had to dodge
roll in to avoid it.

Come to think of it, there were a lot of
boss attacks that felt like they could only be

avoided by exploiting dodge roll iframes,
and that&#39;s always got the heady whiff of bullshit
about it.

It doesn&#39;t seem reasonable to me that we
can survive being at ground zero of a nuclear

blast because we did a
rolly polly just before impact.

You know, my experience with Rembrandt 2 is
kind of the inverse of what I had with Rembrandt

from the arses in that I went in with
the positive feeling and gradually soured to
it over time.

I think the turning point was when I
visited the wibbly wobbly evil purple dimension and

was obliged to explore a very samey desert
for hours on end fighting off endlessly respawning

waves of Amazon delivery drones, trying to
figure out which of the eleven or twelve interchangeable

grindy dungeons I stumbled upon was the
one I was supposed to do to progress in the game

and which would just toss me a new
amulet that&#39;s about as much use for my build as a

pamphlet on the negative health of
Vexxer showing off awesome quickdraw skills.

Some with elaborate boss fights that I&#39;d
be stuck trying to beat for ages because such

things are usually game design shorthand
for &quot;go this way&quot; because I gave myself tendinitis

modelling this bastard&#39;s nipples so
you&#39;d better not miss it, and then afterwards it&#39;s

all like &quot;haha, it was an optional fight all
along, here&#39;s your ring of plus 1.4% pie appreciation
back to combing the desert for you!&quot;

So I did become a slog, and I ultimately
stopped playing in, I don&#39;t know if it was the last

area, certainly felt like one, I was on even
more post-apocalyptic than previously established

post-apocalyptic Earth Earth and tried to
imagine the kill of the first flame from Dark Souls

1, but three times longer and with each of
the black knights replaced by an entire busload

of rascally schoolchildren peppered with
boss fights so immersed in bullshit that only the

tops of their pompadour hairstyles broke
surface, culminating in the wiffiest of them all.

The first phase was bad enough with loads
of mandatory iframe timing, but then the second

phase came and killed both me and any
interest I had in finishing the game in seconds flat.

Some distant twat polished off my whole
health bar in three bites while I could barely see

him through wibbly wobbly red glitch
effects, it was like being beaten to death with a virtual
boy.

And I was the badass gunslinger, remember. What 
would the sodding dog handler have done? I don&#39;t

think there&#39;s a command for &quot;go
straight to the pound and complete your own surrender
